keyTakeAways: The NBA season opens with a record 135 players born outside the U.S., from 43 countries, setting a new record for international representation.
71 of these international players are from Europe, the highest number ever from that continent, indicating growing basketball influence in Europe.
Canada leads with 23 non-U.S. players, followed by France (19) and Australia (13), highlighting strong international talent pipelines.
The Atlanta Hawks have 10 international players on their opening-night roster, tying an NBA record for such representation.
All 30 NBA teams have at least one international player, signaling a global shift in team composition.
The NBA is in talks with FIBA to launch a new league in Europe by 2027, aiming to expand the sport’s reach and elevate the game across the continent.
Players born outside the U.S. have won the last seven NBA MVP awards, a historic streak showing the growing influence of international talent.
LeBron James is on track to break multiple records, including 23rd season, 1,611 regular-season games, and 350 field goals, reinforcing his legacy.
The Brooklyn Nets have no players in the top 100 active scorers, making them one of the youngest and most inexperienced rosters in the league.
Multiple players share common names (e.g., 7 Jordans, 5 Nikolas, 5 Jameses), reflecting cultural and naming trends in basketball.
The 14 millionth point in NBA history is expected to be scored around November 17, 2025, based on average scoring rates.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The 2025 NBA season opens with a record number of international players—135 born outside the U.S., from 43 countries, with 71 from Europe—marking a significant global shift in the league. The Atlanta Hawks tie an NBA record with 10 international players on their opening-night roster, and all 30 teams have at least one international player. This growing international presence is supported by the NBA’s discussions with FIBA to launch a new European league by 2027. Players from countries such as Canada, France, and Greece have been instrumental in this shift, with the last seven MVPs going to non-U.S. players. At the same time, individual milestones are being pursued by stars like LeBron James and coaches like Erik Spoelstra, while teams like the Brooklyn Nets are noted for their youth and relative lack of experience. The article also highlights cultural trends such as common player names and the milestone of the 14 millionth point in NBA history, expected around November 17, 2025.
title: NBA Season Opens with Record International Representation and Global Expansion Plans
